body_html: I went into the tf.moments source and changed it to use supported methods:     diff = math_ops.subtract(y, array_ops.stop_gradient(mean))    variance = math_ops.reduce_mean(        #math_ops.squared_difference(y, array_ops.stop_gradient(mean)),        math_ops.multiply(diff,diff),        axes, So I broke squared_difference down into a subtract and a multiply. On Tuesday, October 23, 2018, 8:35:05 AM EDT, Vadim <notifications@github.com> wrote: dear gbildson, Can you please explain how did you bypassed the usage of tf.moments (in order to calculate the var and then var^0.5 for the instance normalization )? Thanks — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
body_text:
I went into the tf.moments source and changed it to use supported methods:
    diff = math_ops.subtract(y, array_ops.stop_gradient(mean))    variance = math_ops.reduce_mean(        #math_ops.squared_difference(y, array_ops.stop_gradient(mean)),        math_ops.multiply(diff,diff),        axes,
So I broke squared_difference down into a subtract and a multiply.

    On Tuesday, October 23, 2018, 8:35:05 AM EDT, Vadim <notifications@github.com> wrote:


dear gbildson,
Can you please explain how did you bypassed the usage of tf.moments (in order to calculate the var and then var^0.5 for the instance normalization )?

Thanks

—

body:
I went into the tf.moments source and changed it to use supported methods:
    diff = math_ops.subtract(y, array_ops.stop_gradient(mean))    variance = math_ops.reduce_mean(        #math_ops.squared_difference(y, array_ops.stop_gradient(mean)),        math_ops.multiply(diff,diff),        axes,
So I broke squared_difference down into a subtract and a multiply.

    On Tuesday, October 23, 2018, 8:35:05 AM EDT, Vadim <notifications@github.com> wrote:  
 
 
dear gbildson,
Can you please explain how did you bypassed the usage of tf.moments (in order to calculate the var and then var^0.5 for the instance normalization )?

Thanks

—
